thread.title: LOGISTICS: New FedEx Ground plant opens to serve customers from Beaumont to Twentynine Palms
thread.title_full: LOGISTICS: New FedEx Ground plant opens to serve customers from Beaumont to Twentynine Palms - Press Enterprise

author: DEBRA GRUSZECKI
title: LOGISTICS: New FedEx Ground plant opens to serve customers from Beaumont to Twentynine Palms
text:
By DEBRA GRUSZECKI / STAFF WRITER
 Updated: 3:12 p.m. LOGISTICS: New FedEx Ground plant opens to serve customers from Beaumont to Twentynine Palms 1 of 5 More FedEx Ground trucks driven by independent contractors head out of the new facility in Palm Springs on Tuesday, Oct. 12, 2015. The new facility opened Oct. 1 to amp up package volume and shave delivery time in locales from Beaumont and the Salton Sea to Mountain Center, Idywilld, Landers and Twentynine Palms. DEBRA GRUSZECKI , STAFF PHOTO Related article » Working for FedEx A FedEx Ground website describes Sorting and Package Handling jobs. No phone calls.
Here are 5 steps to take:
1) Visit: www.WatchaSort.com
2) Watch a video to hear workers talk about their jobs: http://bit.ly/1Kv5XZc
3) Sign up to attend a Sort Observation – FedEx Ground slang for touring the plant.
4) Respond to the e-mail you may get after the tour. That's your prompt to fill out the application.
5) Nail the interview.
To learn more about FedEx positions: FedEx.com/careers
In the latest logistics move to meet growing consumer demand, FedEx Ground has opened a package sorting and distribution center in Palm Springs just in time to bulk up on deliveries and speed deliveries to customers in a portion of Inland Southern California that is as large as some states.
With just over 60 online shopping days left until Christmas, the 150,000-square-foot center, with 36 loading spaces, opened this month. The facility complements in Bloomington that serves customers farther west.
Developed on land Robert W. Miner had owned along the 10 freeway since 1986, the Palm Springs plant on Indian Canyon Drive is four times bigger than the FedEx Ground plant the package handlers vacated on the outskirts of Desert Hot Springs.
“I love it,” Lomack Gray said as he pumped gasoline into a FedEx Ground truck at a nearby Pilot fueling station for his early-morning runs.
The new FedEx Ground hub, built by The Kiernan Companies of Coronado, will receive, sort and deliver boxed and sealed packages to customers in a coverage area that stretches from Beaumont east to Niland, and from Idyllwild north to Twentynine Palms.
“We got a new building; new uniforms,” Gray said. “And everything’s more organized.”
Gray said morale is better, too, because the streamlined operation has already reduced down-time to load the fleet of trucks and pull out of the lot.
“Every minute counts in this business,” he said. “Anytime we can trim off an hour is a big thing for us.”
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, delivery and other truck drivers comprise one of the largest occupations in the U.S., holding 3.2 million jobs. It’s also one of the fastest growing.
The FedEx Ground center’s opening comes at a time when logistics centers, warehouses and industrial property are blazing ahead. A recent forecast by UC Riverside’s Center for Economic Forecasting and Development has called industrial property growth the “star child” of Inland Southern California.
The region has become a hotbed for construction and warehouse occupancy in this realm: The lineup of product handlers moving into big warehouse space in the Inland Empire include: Amazon, Amrapur Overseas, reLogistics Services, the German grocer Aldi and Deckers Outdoor.
Christopher Gopal, senior fellow at Claremont Graduate University’s Drucker Center for Supply Chain and Logistics in Claremont, said the FedEx Ground plant is a big deal.
“Any increase in supply chain and logistics is a key driver for the whole Inland Empire area,” Gopal said.
“The rise in e-commerce is driving a lot of this,” Gopal added. “With e-Commerce and Omni channel fulfillment on the rise, there’s no way to go but to see plants like FedEx Ground increase operations.
FedEx Ground spokeswoman Nikki Mendicino said the new Palm Springs facility is part of a nationwide network expansion to increase daily package volume capacity and enhance the speed and service capabilities across the FedEx Ground network.
The Palm Springs site was picked for its proximity to major highways – it is a stone’s throw from the I-10 eastbound exit – customer base, range of distribution centers and local workforce, she said. Unlike FedEx offices that deal with customers, this plant is not open to the public.
